com.mousebird.maply

Class GlobeController

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.mousebird.maply.MaplyBaseController
      • com.mousebird.maply.GlobeController
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    android.view.Choreographer.FrameCallback, android.view.View.OnTouchListener

    public class GlobeController
extends MaplyBaseController
implements android.view.View.OnTouchListener, android.view.Choreographer.FrameCallback
    The GlobeController is the main object in the Maply library when using a 3D globe. Toolkit users add and remove their geometry through here.

    The controller starts by creating an OpenGL ES surface and handling all the various setup between Maply and that surface. It also kicks off a LayerThread, which it uses to queue requests to the rest of Maply.

    Once the controller is set up and running the toolkit user can make calls to add and remove geometry. Those calls are thread safe.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description

      Use this delegate when you want user interface feedback from the maply controller.

      class  GlobeController.ViewState
      This encapulates the entire view state.

        Description copied from class: MaplyBaseController

      • setKeepNorthUp

        public void setKeepNorthUp(boolean newVal)
        Set the keep north up parameter on or off. On means we will always rotate the globe to keep north up. Off means we won't.

        Set the zoom limits for the globe.
        Parameters:
        inMin - Closest the user is allowed to zoom in.
        inMax - Farthest the user is allowed to zoom out.

      • displayPointFromGeo

        public Point3d displayPointFromGeo(Point3d geoPt)
        Return a point in display space. Display space is close to what's rendered. For the globe it's a model space based on a radius of 1.0.

      • findHeightToViewBounds

        public double findHeightToViewBounds(Mbr mbr,
                                     Point2d pos)
        For a given position, how high do we have to be to see the given area.

        Even for 2D maps we represent things in terms of height.

        Parameters:
        mbr - Bounding box for the area we want to see in geographic (radians).
        pos - Center of the viewing area in geographic (radians).
        Returns:
        Returns a height for the viewer.

      • setPositionGeo

        public void setPositionGeo(double x,
                           double y,
                           double z)
        Set the current view position.
        Parameters:
        x - Horizontal location of the center of the screen in geographic radians (not degrees).
        y - Vertical location of the center of the screen in geographic radians (not degrees).
        z - Height above the map in display units.

      • getPositionGeo

        public Point3d getPositionGeo()
        Returns the position in on the globe in terms of longitude and latitude in radians and height. Height is height above the globe. The globe has a radius of 1.0.

      • isCompletelySetup

                               double y,
                               double z,
                               double howLong)
        Animate to a new view position
        Parameters:
        x - Horizontal location of the center of the screen in geographic radians (not degrees).
        y - Vertical location of the center of the screen in geographic radians (not degrees).
        z - Height above the map in display units.
        howLong - Time (in seconds) to animate.

      • setAutoRotate

        public void setAutoRotate(float autoRotateInterval,
                          float autoRotateDegrees)
        This turns on an auto-rotate mode. The globe will start rotating after a delay by the given number of degrees per second. Very pleasant.
        Parameters:
        autoRotateInterval - Wait this number of seconds after user interaction to auto rotate.
        autoRotateDegrees - Rotate this number of degrees (not radians) per second.
